Focusing on the ideas of
tolerance and respecting others,
the International Festival will take
place this year from October 30
to November 7. Throughout the
week, many ethnic clubs will
stage an assortment of activities.
Co-chairpersons Thao La and
Erick Santos have planned the
festival since August, with help
from seven sub-chairpersons and
a student committee comprised of
two members from each participating club. According to Santos, "A lot more work has been
put into it this year. Last year's
festival was only organized for
two or three weeks, and not as
successful as the people wanted."
Santos said that "last year there
was a big issue about people not
respecting each other, and the
ethnic clubs got together and
basically said let's do something
about it."
La added that the Black
Student Union represented a major part of the initial effort
because it believed it was a being
treated unfairly at Hopkins.
The festival now provides the

Hopkins community with a
"flavor of all different cultures,"
said Santos.
Increased club participation has
helped to "promote diversity,"
added La. Fifteen ethnic clubs are
involved this year, instead of the
five that worked last year. "Each
club is willing to share something
of itself with the Hopkins community," maintained La.
During the week, each club
will hold several activities. At
least three or four events will occur each day, ending with the International Dinner on November
7 and the appearance of
Rafael Hernandez-Colon, Governor of Puerto Rico, who will
speak about the force of Hispanic
politics in the United States.
The dinner plays an important
role as part of the festivities, said
La, who added that last year's
dinner was such an immense success that two seatings have been
arranged for this year, at 5 and
8 p.m.
Each club is expected to make
one to three dishes, serving about
250 people each. Five hundred
people are expected for each
seating in Levering. During the

dinner, groups will play ethnic
music.
Dessert will be served in the
Great Hall, to the accompaniment
ofjazz music and a string quartet.
La mentioned the dinner's potential for success but "hopes that
this year, faculty and administration will participate."
Funds for the festival amount
to $8000. Of this sum, approximately $3700 came from the
Student Activities Commission,
$2500 came from the Student
Council, $600 from the Hopkins
Organization for Programming,
and $350 came from each of the
sophomore, junior and senior
classes.
"We had a big battle with the
SAC to get the money we needed," said Santos.
However, La said that better
organization eliminated many of
last year's problems. "The
hardest work is encouraging each
club to put something worthwhile
out," she said. "We can only
hope that people will come see the
international exhibits and enjoy
the ethnic culture displayed."

Throughout the investigations of the
committees many members found recurring issues that seemed to underlie the main
problems at Hopkins.
The lack of opportunities for interaction
between groups was one issue addressed
in the Subcommittee on Interpersonal Relations' report that was expressed by all
those interviewed.
"There are a number of sets and subsets
of groups functioning in isolation," said
B.J. Norris, vice president for communications and public affairs.
Noting the "cumbersome, confusing administrative structure," recommendations
included the construction of a student union
and three or four informal gathering
places.
Regarding the issue of women and
minorities, committee members emphasized the "lack of diversity, intolerance of
differences, and an apparent inability to
live and work together with respect and
civility" as the main cause of problems in
the Homewood community.
"Women and race/ethnic minorities feel
a great sense of disenfrachisement and second class citizenship," said Jomills Braddock, principle research scientist at the
Center for Research in Elementary and
Middle Schools. "The objective reality is
that there is an underrepresentation of
women and minorities in the Homewood
community and this becomes more pro-

nounced as you go up the hierarchical
order."
The development of a policy on freedom
of expression and a "clear and unqualified
commitment" to the improvement of conditions for women and minorities on the
Homewood campus were major recommendations from this committee.
Directly related to student life, the Sub_
committee on Student-Centered Issues had
two main objectives, "to assess the current climate at Homewood as viewed by
students and to attempt to determine the

Racism: Alive and Well
Around the country incidents are occurring which, while increasing racial tensions
on their respective college campuses, more
odiously indicate shameful prejudice. For
the most part, the incidents can not be clearly deemed as racism—necessarily; the implication of intolerance, however, is not
easily muted.
At Mississippi State University in late
August, a black student drowned after being thrown into a swimming pool by three
white students. The police investigation,
one being protested by the NAACP, corroborated the students' claim that they had
thrown him in in jest.
At Michigan State University in late
September, a Navajo Indian has claimed
that her fellow band members forcefully
shaved the back of her neck despite her protests that such an act defied her religious
beliefs and heritage.
The University of Illinois has been the
location of a number of indecencies. A
brochure which advertised an upcoming
workshop on long-distance relationships included, for illustration, a section of a Montana map showing "Nigger Mountain." An
apology was quickly issued, however the
map choice was perceived as particularly
distasteful following a summer at U. Illinois
in which their Latin cultural office had been
vandalized and a conservative paper had
advertised for a "token minority" to serve
on the staff.
Univesity of Massachusetts at Amherst
erupted on two occasions within the past
year. Last October, a brawl broke out,
resulting in the hospitalization of ten people. The university administration has admitted that there was a racial dimension to
the fighting, although it doubts there was
racial motivation initially. This was followed in May by a skirmish between three
black students and members of a fraternity.
The issue in these cases is not that there
is some oppressed side telling the truth
while insidious members of some confident
majority refute them. No more appropriate
is a real concern that there are a growing

number of racists who are now more openly
expressing their bigotry. What is disturbing is the inherent insensitivity to others
which pervades, for example, the attitude
behind callous practical jokes (which we
may have seen have disastorous reprecussions in Mississippi).
We are fortunate and yet unfortunate that
conspicuously distasteful—or worse,
damaging—events have not fallen on
minorities at Homewood. Despite relief that
no one has been hurt, such a painful occurrence can bring an emotionally charged issue up front, while more rational approaches might not.
The problems of a deeply underlying lack
of respect for minorities (and women) is
discussed quite clearly in the Human
Climate Task Force report. Its observations
from contributing students, staff and faculty
describe a tacit repression of minorities,
while individuals describe their constant
struggle to earn the respect of the community and expand into it from their small
compartments.
Many of the suggestions made for sensitizing the community to the values of
others are well-directed at the "root" of
the problem: a lack of education about and
exposure to others. The hope is that such
exposure leads to understanding, or at least
fosters greater tolerance of others.
The International Festival, beginning today and continuing into next weekend, falls
well in line with these desires, although the
underlying message threatens to be lost in
a quagmire of sub-titled movies, the success of the International Festival is almost
immeasurable, but it should contribute to
the overall effort of understanding.
Given that a concerned rush for an improved attitude toward minorities requires
some impetus, perhaps the task force report
can be cohesive enough a reflection, and
in that sense definitive enough an opinion
to stir activity. It only takes a look at other
campuses to see the backlash that results
from inertia.

Party Time with the Profs
It seems that just when you're ready to
condemn Hopkins to hopeless seriousness,
some students get their acts together and
arrange social activities with real potential.
Last Friday's Hoppy Hour, put on by the
Hopkins Organization for Programming
(HOP), was a real success. Born out of the
spirit of the Human Climate Task Force
'Social Hours' held last semester, the HOP
has managed to attract students and administrators alike to this late-afternoon
event. After struggling through various
channels, they've even made it official by
stocking alcohol: who can refuse a 75-cent
beer and free food?
Social Hours were well received by
students, in large measure not because of
Dan Naiman and Friends, however talented
they may be, but because they were able
to casually intermingle with faculty and
administrators.

It would be nice to think that the Social
Hours were enlightening as well as fun; the
Task Force report encourages such intermingling for its own sake in that it fosters
strengthening of community and facilitates
discourse.
Due to the success of last Friday's Hoppy Hour, the HOP has scheduled another
for this afternoon. Rumour has it that there
are plans to make this a regular event. We
hope that all members of the community—
faculty, staff and students— will use the
weekly Hoppy Hours as opportunities to get
together at the end of a week and talk about
something other than classes, for a change.
The Hoppy Hour is an excellent way of
making some of the Task Force's ideals
reality. It is up to the Homewood community to make use of this opportunity and break
down some of the mental barriers which
separate students and faculty.

Dr. Gryder,"the pre-med guru"
by Vivian Lan
Every student at Hopkins interested in the health professions
will eventually meet Professor of
Chemistry Dr. John W. Gryder.
Some freshmen are first introduced to him in Introductory
Chemistry. Others will met him
in an interview or consultation for
medical school. He is "the one
pre-meds make fun of."
Gryder, who is considered by
many to be the pre-med guru, was
raised in Los Angeles. He attended the California Institute of
Technology as an undergraduate
and then did his graduate studies
at Columbia University. He
describes himself as being "a
typical nerd" during his years as
a student.
Gryder came to Hopkins In:
1949 as an instructor of quantitative analysis. He was appointed professor in 1966, and
during that interim taught
"everything but organic
chemistry."
Contrary to popular belief,
Gryder did not invent the catalytic
converter (that muth despised
automobile smog-control device).
He said the rumor arose because
of research he did on catalysis.
"People have been saying that for
years, and I keep denying it," he
said.
Gryder became the chief health

professions advisor in the early
'70s. Before that time, there had
been no formal advising structure. He says, "I kind of fell into the position. Quite a few
undergrads were asking me for
advice. — Gryder was also
Associate Dean of the School of
Arts and Sciences for three years.
Teaching, however, has always
been Gryder's vocation. He
recalls, "A nice high school
teacher told me that the next best
thing to being a teacher is to be
a professor." He adds, "I came
from a family that never went to
college." He particularly enjoys
teaching freshmen because
"they're still enthusiastic and not
jaded like the rest of us. But some
feel that I squelch their
enthusiasm."
Gryder's teaching style is
characterized by a dialogue with
students, often in a class of 200.
In his lectures, he wants to create
and balance the "right amount of
confusion" because he is convinced that "people need to work
out of a maze." Also, he wants
students to differentiate between
important and unimportant information by themselves.
Gryder currently teaches Intro
Chemistry and an Atoms and
Molecules course. In his spare
time, Gryder pursues his interests
in photography, traveling, and
computers.

wonder, your head still buzzing

Seuss' The Seven Lady
Godivas, a fairy tale for adults.

book did not immediately achieve

Indeed, Dr. Seuss himself said
that his book was "promptly remaindered in Schultze Cigar
Stores." Today, however, with
original copies of Seven Lady
Godivas selling for as much as
five hunclred dollars on the collectors market, we plebians have
been admitted to the somewhat
more mature although mercifully no more serious world of Dr.
Seuss.

raging horse, the Seven Lady
Godivas resolve not to marry

read that one finds oneself grinning once in a while for no reason

around so you open it at any time
you need to get away from the
Peloponnessian War for just a

minute.
Childhood only ends if you let,
and with Dr. Seuss hanging
around I see no reason to let that
happen. Dr. Seuss is alive and
well in La Jolla, California, and
as recently as 1984 won a Pulitzer
Prize Special Citation as well as
having garnered almost every existing children's book award.

shadow of such a guy. Just read,
enjoy, and if you feel the need for
a bedtime story, bribe your
roommate into reading you The
Seven Lady Godivas. Just
remember not to be a monster,
because roomates don't have to
take it; and chuck the Frank
Herbert novel, Dr. Seuss is
where it's at, and Godiva's
Coventry countryside is the place
to be.

small and erratic, his temperature
begins to fall at a regular rate, his
heartbeat slows, and eyes slowly
roll from side to side. This interval lasts some five minutes. Stage
2 extends for some forty-five
minutes and is characterized by
tossing and turning. Brain waves
become irregular with occasional
peaks and valleys. The eyes
become still while heart and

breathing rates decrease slightly.
By stage 3, the sleeper has fallen
into a deeper sleep and his brain
waves
become
slower.
Temperature is falling and so too
is blood pressure. The fourth
stage finds the individual in his
deepest sleep. Slow delta waves
in the brain are indicative of this
period. The heart and breathing
rate also have reached their
lowest levels at this point. During this interval, the sleeper is extremely difficult to awaken. The
brain may hear sounds, but they
do not register in the conscious
mind. People who tend to mutter
or talk or sleepwalk will tend to
do so in this stage. After ninety
minutes, the sleeper will re-enter
stage 3 and then 2, and finally the
first stage. Instead of waking
though, the indiviclual will enter
REM (rapid eye movement).,
One's eyes will begin to dart back
and forth; brain waves become
short and erratic. Most dreams
will exist during this REM state.
The muscles are limp and immobile except for the arms and
legs which often twitch. Blood
pressure and breathing rates
skyrocket even though the sleeper
may be experiencing a perfectly
calm and peaceful dream. The
first REM period is short, lasting
only ten to fifteen minutes. The
sleeper will then go through the
stages again and participate in
REM again, only for a longer
duration. REM sleep is so men-

tally and physically active that it
is equal to an equal period ofjogging. The individual will spend
approximately 'A of his sleeping
time in REM. Finally one
awakens; temperature, blood
pressure, breathing and heart
rates return to normal.
A dream can be defined as being some mental, visual experience during sleep that we had
that night. A dream often begins
with a bizarre or illogical event
followed by a story sequence for
a few seconds or minutes until the
scene suddenly shifts. Each story
unfolds in about the same amount
of time that would be required for
the same sequence of events in
'waking life.'
There has been long-time
speculation about why people
dream. Some say that it is a tool,
and if properly manipulated, it
can solve problems, aid memory,
help one to overcome crises, and
even heal wounds. Others say that
it is the brain's attempt to clear
the mind of unnecessary information. Sigmund Freud, the pioneer
of dream research, considered
this to be the simplest case of
wish fulfillment.
Dreams have been shown to
solve problems. In 1913, Niels
Bohr had a dream where the sun
was a fixed center, and the
planets were the electrons held in
an energy field. This eventually
led to the system of quantum
mechanics in physics. Elias Howe

had a nightmare where he dreamed that if he could not produce a
machine that could sew, he would
die by a spear. As the spears approached him in his dream, he
noticed that they eye-shaped
holes. When he awoke, he realized that the eyes of the needle on
the sewing machine that he tad
been working on needed to be
near the point of the needle.
Can a dream see into the
future? Although this hypothesis
seems absurd, there have been
many unusual occurrences which
prove otherwise. The most incredible incident must be that of
Robert Morris. He dreamed that
he was about to be shot to death
by one of the big guns on a naval
vessel he was soon scheduled to
visit. He attempted to cancel the
visit but the captain promised to
withold any gunfire during the inspection and so Morris complied
with his demand. The tour ended
with a salute (without the traditional fire from the guns until
Morris reached the shore and
raised his hand.) On the trip back,
Morris tried to brush a fly off his
shoulder, and the gunman assumed that he was on shore and so
proceeded to fire the guns. A tiny
fragment of the discharge hit
Morris and fatally wounded him.
A nightmare is a dream filled
with terror and fear. The question
of why nightmares exist has been
in dispute for a long time. People once thought that a

.....

nightmare's purpose was to
punish oneself for something he
or she had done. However, today's scientists attribute
nightmares to be the mind's way
of dealing with overwhelming
fears. Another hypothesis is that
indigestion or improper blood circulation or breathing causes
nightmares.
One has four to five dreams
every night, yet most people can
only remember one or two
dreams every night.
There are many theories concerning this problem. Many feel that
dreams are to be forgotten
because the brain is attempting to
rid itself of worries through
dreams and trying to remember
these dreams would serve no purpose. Others feel that since the
REM periods are so short in the
beginning, there is now way that
one could remember them. This
area continues to be disputed and
will be for time to come.
Sleep and dreams are topics
that have been researched for
many years. Much has been
speculated but a great deal of
uncertainty still exists.

book Sleep—The Mysterious
Third of Your Life by Jonathon
and Marianna Kastner.

Racism: Alive and Well
Around the country incidents are occurring which, while increasing racial tensions
on their respective college campuses, more
odiously indicate shameful prejudice. For
the most part, the incidents can not be clearly deemed as racism—necessarily; the implication of intolerance, however, is not
easily muted.
At Mississippi State University in late
August, a black student drowned after being thrown into a swimming pool by three
white students. The police investigation,
one being protested by the NAACP, corroborated the students' claim that they had
thrown him in in jest.
At Michigan State University in late
September, a Navajo Indian has claimed
that her fellow band members forcefully
shaved the back of her neck despite her protests that such an act defied her religious
beliefs and heritage.
The University of Illinois has been the
location of a number of indecencies. A
brochure which advertised an upcoming
workshop on long-distance relationships included, for illustration, a section of a Montana map showing "Nigger Mountain." An
apology was quickly issued, however the
map choice was perceived as particularly
distasteful following a summer at U. Illinois
in which their Latin cultural office had been
vandalized and a conservative paper had
advertised for a "token minority" to serve
on the staff.
Univesity of Massachusetts at Amherst
erupted on two occasions within the past
year. Last October, a brawl broke out,
resulting in the hospitalization of ten people. The university administration has admitted that there was a racial dimension to
the fighting, although it doubts there was
racial motivation initially. This was followed in May by a skirmish between three
black students and members of a fraternity.
The issue in these cases is not that there
is some oppressed side telling the truth
while insidious members of some confident
majority refute them. No more appropriate
is a real concern that there are a growing

number of racists who are now more openly
expressing their bigotry. What is disturbing is the inherent insensitivity to others
which pervades, for example, the attitude
behind callous practical jokes (which we
may have seen have disastorous reprecussions in Mississippi).
We are fortunate and yet unfortunate that
conspicuously distasteful—or worse,
damaging—events have not fallen on
minorities at Homewood. Despite relief that
no one has been hurt, such a painful occurrence can bring an emotionally charged issue up front, while more rational approaches might not.
The problems of a deeply underlying lack
of respect for minorities (and women) is
discussed quite clearly in the Human
Climate Task Force report. Its observations
from contributing students, staff and faculty
describe a tacit repression of minorities,
while individuals describe their constant
struggle to earn the respect of the community and expand into it from their small
compartments.
Many of the suggestions made for sensitizing the community to the values of
others are well-directed at the "root" of
the problem: a lack of education about and
exposure to others. The hope is that such
exposure leads to understanding, or at least
fosters greater tolerance of others.
The International Festival, beginning today and continuing into next weekend, falls
well in line with these desires, although the
underlying message threatens to be lost in
a quagmire of sub-titled movies, the success of the International Festival is almost
immeasurable, but it should contribute to
the overall effort of understanding.
Given that a concerned rush for an improved attitude toward minorities requires
some impetus, perhaps the task force report
can be cohesive enough a reflection, and
in that sense definitive enough an opinion
to stir activity. It only takes a look at other
campuses to see the backlash that results
from inertia.

Dr. Gryder,"the pre-med guru"
by Vivian Lan
Every student at Hopkins interested in the health professions
will eventually meet Professor of
Chemistry Dr. John W. Gryder.
Some freshmen are first introduced to him in Introductory
Chemistry. Others will met him
in an interview or consultation for
medical school. He is "the one
pre-meds make fun of."
Gryder, who is considered by
many to be the pre-med guru, was
raised in Los Angeles. He attended the California Institute of
Technology as an undergraduate
and then did his graduate studies
at Columbia University. He
describes himself as being "a
typical nerd" during his years as
a student.
Gryder came to Hopkins In:
1949 as an instructor of quantitative analysis. He was appointed professor in 1966, and
during that interim taught
"everything but organic
chemistry."
Contrary to popular belief,
Gryder did not invent the catalytic
converter (that muth despised
automobile smog-control device).
He said the rumor arose because
of research he did on catalysis.
"People have been saying that for
years, and I keep denying it," he
said.
Gryder became the chief health

professions advisor in the early
'70s. Before that time, there had
been no formal advising structure. He says, "I kind of fell into the position. Quite a few
undergrads were asking me for
advice. — Gryder was also
Associate Dean of the School of
Arts and Sciences for three years.
Teaching, however, has always
been Gryder's vocation. He
recalls, "A nice high school
teacher told me that the next best
thing to being a teacher is to be
a professor." He adds, "I came
from a family that never went to
college." He particularly enjoys
teaching freshmen because
"they're still enthusiastic and not
jaded like the rest of us. But some
feel that I squelch their
enthusiasm."
Gryder's teaching style is
characterized by a dialogue with
students, often in a class of 200.
In his lectures, he wants to create
and balance the "right amount of
confusion" because he is convinced that "people need to work
out of a maze." Also, he wants
students to differentiate between
important and unimportant information by themselves.
Gryder currently teaches Intro
Chemistry and an Atoms and
Molecules course. In his spare
time, Gryder pursues his interests
in photography, traveling, and
computers.

will, this scene:
It is twenty years into your
future. Your five-year-old boy
went straight to sleep at eight

smiles and locks his/herself in the
bathroom. Sara can be a monster
if she wants to. You look little
Sara in -the eyes. She grimaces.
She is about to become the Sara
Monster. In the background you
hear water rusing into the tub and
realize that you're in this by
yourself. How do you get Sarah
into her futon? You smile. You

know what to do.
You read her a Dr. Seuss book,
the best of all bed-time stories.
Sarah leaps straight under her
blankets and away she goes with
the Cat in the Hat, or maybe eats
Green Eggs and Ham (O000h
Guh-ross, you can hear her say),
and before you know it, the
Monster has gone away and little
Sarah is sound asleep. Shutting
off the lights and quietly closing
the door, you slip into the
hallway. You want to fall asleep
to a good book, but the murder
mystery nexti to your bed won't
quite cut it. What to read, you
wonder, your head still buzzing
with images of the Cat in the Hat.
Well, guess what. You're in
luck. In September of 1987, Random House re-released Dr.
Seuss' The Seven Lady
Godivas, a fairy tale for adults.
Originally published in 1939, the

book did not immediately achieve
the acclaim it so richly deserves.
Indeed, Dr. Seuss himself said
that his book was "promptly remaindered in Schultze Cigar
Stores." Today, however, with
original copies of Seven Lady
Godivas selling for as much as
five hunclred dollars on the collectors market, we plebians have
been admitted to the somewhat
more mature although mercifully no more serious world of Dr.
Seuss.
After the tragic death of their
beloved father at the hoofs of a
raging horse, the Seven Lady
Godivas resolve not to marry
their seven beloved spouses, the
Peepings (Tom, Dick, Harrry,
Jack, Drexel, Sylvester and Frelinghuysen) until they have avenged their father's death. The
Godivas (Clementina, Dorcas,
Arabella, Mitzi, Lulu, Gussie,

and Hedwig)set out to do this by
finding out seven items of Horse
Sense, each sister responsible for
one Sense after which she may
marry.
Over almost a lifetime, the
Godivas, in all of their stark naked glory, find out the true meanings of such expressions as
"Don't ever look a gift horse in
the mouth," "Don't put the cart
before the horse," "You can lead
a horse to water but you can't
make him drink," and even why
horseshoes are lucky.
An authentic Dr. Seuss story to
the last line, complete with the
classic illustrations by the master
himself, the book is such a joy to
read that one finds oneself grinning once in a while for no reason
at all and leaving the book lying
around so you open it at any time
you need to get away from the
Peloponnessian War for just a

minute.
Childhood only ends if you let,
and with Dr. Seuss hanging
around I see no reason to let that
happen. Dr. Seuss is alive and
well in La Jolla, California, and
as recently as 1984 won a Pulitzer
Prize Special Citation as well as
having garnered almost every existing children's book award.
But what are awards in the
shadow of such a guy. Just read,
enjoy, and if you feel the need for
a bedtime story, bribe your
roommate into reading you The
Seven Lady Godivas. Just
remember not to be a monster,
because roomates don't have to
take it; and chuck the Frank
Herbert novel, Dr. Seuss is
where it's at, and Godiva's
Coventry countryside is the place
to be.

Sleep: Just what is this mysterious unknown?
by Sujay Vora
Sleep—Why do we sleep? why
do some people need more sleep
than others? What is the purpose
of dreaming? Why do some people sleepwalk and others have insomnia? There are no simple
answers to these questions but
many advancements have been
made in sleep and dream
research. However, as you may
well see, it is also an interval of
complex brain activity and, at
times, of actual physical
movement.
The pattern in which one goes
to sleep has been found to be very
similar in most people. Following the activities of a typical
sleeper through a night's sleep,
one initially sees sleep overcome
the individual with muscle relaxation. The sleeper will then doze,
wake again, then fall back to
sleep quickly—this period is
known as the threshold of sleep.
The individual will finally experience the five stages of sleep.
In stage 1, one's brain waves are
small and erratic, his temperature
begins to fall at a regular rate, his
heartbeat slows, and eyes slowly
roll from side to side. This interval lasts some five minutes. Stage
2 extends for some forty-five
minutes and is characterized by
tossing and turning. Brain waves
become irregular with occasional
peaks and valleys. The eyes
become still while heart and

breathing rates decrease slightly.
By stage 3, the sleeper has fallen
into a deeper sleep and his brain
waves
become
slower.
Temperature is falling and so too
is blood pressure. The fourth
stage finds the individual in his
deepest sleep. Slow delta waves
in the brain are indicative of this
period. The heart and breathing
rate also have reached their
lowest levels at this point. During this interval, the sleeper is extremely difficult to awaken. The
brain may hear sounds, but they
do not register in the conscious
mind. People who tend to mutter
or talk or sleepwalk will tend to
do so in this stage. After ninety
minutes, the sleeper will re-enter
stage 3 and then 2, and finally the
first stage. Instead of waking
though, the indiviclual will enter
REM (rapid eye movement).,
One's eyes will begin to dart back
and forth; brain waves become
short and erratic. Most dreams
will exist during this REM state.
The muscles are limp and immobile except for the arms and
legs which often twitch. Blood
pressure and breathing rates
skyrocket even though the sleeper
may be experiencing a perfectly
calm and peaceful dream. The
first REM period is short, lasting
only ten to fifteen minutes. The
sleeper will then go through the
stages again and participate in
REM again, only for a longer
duration. REM sleep is so men-

tally and physically active that it
is equal to an equal period ofjogging. The individual will spend
approximately 'A of his sleeping
time in REM. Finally one
awakens; temperature, blood
pressure, breathing and heart
rates return to normal.
A dream can be defined as being some mental, visual experience during sleep that we had
that night. A dream often begins
with a bizarre or illogical event
followed by a story sequence for
a few seconds or minutes until the
scene suddenly shifts. Each story
unfolds in about the same amount
of time that would be required for
the same sequence of events in
'waking life.'
There has been long-time
speculation about why people
dream. Some say that it is a tool,
and if properly manipulated, it
can solve problems, aid memory,
help one to overcome crises, and
even heal wounds. Others say that
it is the brain's attempt to clear
the mind of unnecessary information. Sigmund Freud, the pioneer
of dream research, considered
this to be the simplest case of
wish fulfillment.
Dreams have been shown to
solve problems. In 1913, Niels
Bohr had a dream where the sun
was a fixed center, and the
planets were the electrons held in
an energy field. This eventually
led to the system of quantum
mechanics in physics. Elias Howe

had a nightmare where he dreamed that if he could not produce a
machine that could sew, he would
die by a spear. As the spears approached him in his dream, he
noticed that they eye-shaped
holes. When he awoke, he realized that the eyes of the needle on
the sewing machine that he tad
been working on needed to be
near the point of the needle.
Can a dream see into the
future? Although this hypothesis
seems absurd, there have been
many unusual occurrences which
prove otherwise. The most incredible incident must be that of
Robert Morris. He dreamed that
he was about to be shot to death
by one of the big guns on a naval
vessel he was soon scheduled to
visit. He attempted to cancel the
visit but the captain promised to
withold any gunfire during the inspection and so Morris complied
with his demand. The tour ended
with a salute (without the traditional fire from the guns until
Morris reached the shore and
raised his hand.) On the trip back,
Morris tried to brush a fly off his
shoulder, and the gunman assumed that he was on shore and so
proceeded to fire the guns. A tiny
fragment of the discharge hit
Morris and fatally wounded him.
A nightmare is a dream filled
with terror and fear. The question
of why nightmares exist has been
in dispute for a long time. People once thought that a

.....

nightmare's purpose was to
punish oneself for something he
or she had done. However, today's scientists attribute
nightmares to be the mind's way
of dealing with overwhelming
fears. Another hypothesis is that
indigestion or improper blood circulation or breathing causes
nightmares.
One has four to five dreams
every night, yet most people can
only remember one or two
dreams every night.
There are many theories concerning this problem. Many feel that
dreams are to be forgotten
because the brain is attempting to
rid itself of worries through
dreams and trying to remember
these dreams would serve no purpose. Others feel that since the
REM periods are so short in the
beginning, there is now way that
one could remember them. This
area continues to be disputed and
will be for time to come.
Sleep and dreams are topics
that have been researched for
many years. Much has been
speculated but a great deal of
uncertainty still exists.
The information from this article comes primarily from the
book Sleep—The Mysterious
Third of Your Life by Jonathon
and Marianna Kastner.
